It is usually eaten with the crust, but some eaters or preparers may remove the crust due to a personal preference or style of serving, as with finger sandwiches served with <a href="/wiki/Afternoon_tea" title="Afternoon tea" class="mw-redirect">afternoon tea</a>. Some of the softest bread, including <a href="/wiki/Wonder_Bread" title="Wonder Bread">Wonder Bread</a>, is referred to as "balloon bread".
</p><p>Though white "sandwich bread" is the most popular, Americans are trending toward more <a href="/w/index.php?title=Artisanal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Artisanal (page does not exist)">artisanal</a> breads. Different regions of the country feature certain ethnic bread varieties including the French <a href="/wiki/Baguette" title="Baguette">baguette</a>, the Ashkenazi Jewish <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">bagel</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scali_bread&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scali bread (page does not exist)">scali</a> (an Italian-style bread made in <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New England (page does not exist)">New England</a>), <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native American</a> <a href="/wiki/Frybread" title="Frybread">frybread</a> (a product of hardship, developed during the Indian resettlements of the 19th century), and Jewish rye, a bread commonly associated with <a href="/wiki/Delicatessen" title="Delicatessen">delicatessen</a> cuisine.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Religious_significance">Religious significance</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Methodistcommunion6.jpg" title="File:Methodistcommunion6.jpg">File:Methodistcommunion6.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a> (also called Holy Communion or the Lord’s Supper) is considered a sacrament, ordinance, or equivalent in most Christian denominations.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Abrahamic_Religions"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Abrahamic_Religions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abrahamic Religions (page does not exist)">Abrahamic Religions</a></span></h3>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> festival of <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Passover</a>, only unleavened bread is eaten, in commemoration of the flight from slavery in Egypt. The Israelites did not have enough time to allow their bread to rise, and so ate only unleavened bread (<i><a href="/wiki/Matzoh" title="Matzoh" class="mw-redirect">matzoh</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian (page does not exist)">Christian</a> ritual of the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a>, bread symbolically represents the body of Christ, and is eaten as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sacrament&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sacrament (page does not exist)">sacrament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Specific aspects of the ritual itself, including the composition of the bread, vary from denomination to denomination. The differences in the practice of the Eucharist stem from different descriptions and depictions of the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a> which provides the scriptural basis for the Eucharist.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Synoptic_Gospels" title="Synoptic Gospels">Synoptic Gospels</a> present the Last Supper as a Passover meal and suggest that the bread at the Last Supper would be unleavened. However in the chronology in Gospel of John, the Last Supper occurred the day before Passover suggesting that the bread would be leavened. Despite this point of disagreement, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Florence" title="Council of Florence">Council of Florence</a> of the Catholic church agreed that “the body of Christ is truly confected in both unleavened and leavened wheat bread, and priests should confect the body of Christ in either”.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Paganism"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paganism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paganism (page does not exist)">Paganism</a></span></h3>
<p>Some traditions of <a href="/wiki/Wicca" title="Wicca">Wicca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neo-Paganism" title="Neo-Paganism" class="mw-redirect">Neo-Paganism</a> consume bread as part of their religious rituals, attaching varied symbolism to the act.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Anti-bread_movements">Anti-bread movements</span></h2>
<p>Although eaten by nearly all people, some critics have rejected bread entirely or rejected types of bread that they consider inferior.  The criticisms depended on the time and place:  whole grain bread has been criticized as being unrefined, and white bread as being unhealthfully processed; homemade bread was deemed unsanitary, and factory-made bread was deemed adulterated, and so forth.<sup id="cite_ref-Copeland_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Copeland-34">[34]</a></sup>  <i>Amylophobia</i>, literally "fear of starch", was one such movement in the US during the 1920s and 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-Copeland_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Copeland-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the United States, bread sales have gone down 11.3% in the past five years <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:When&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:When (page does not exist)">Template:When</a>. This statistic reflects a change in the types of food from which Americans are getting their carbohydrates.  It is also possible that the popularity of the gluten-free diet has affected the decrease in bread sales.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_Medicine">In Medicine</span></h2>
<p>The ancient Egyptians used moldy bread to treat infections that arose from dirt in burn wounds. <sup id="cite_ref-Pe.C4.87anac-_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pe.C4.87anac--54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>

</dt>
</dl>

</p>

</li>

</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li>Kaplan, Steven Laurence: <i>Good Bread is Back: A Contemporary History of French Bread, the Way It Is Made, and the People Who Make It</i>. Durham/ London: Duke University Press, 2006. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780822338338" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-8223-3833-8</a>
</li>
<li> Jacob, Heinrich Eduard: <i>Six Thousand Years of Bread. Its Holy and Unholy History</i>. Garden City / New York: Doubleday, Doran and Comp., 1944. New 1997: New York: Lyons &amp; Burford, Publishers (Foreword by Lynn Alley), <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1558215751" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-55821-575-1</a> &amp;lt
</li>
<li> Spiekermann, Uwe: <i>Brown Bread for Victory: German and British Wholemeal Politics in the Inter-War Period</i>, in: Trentmann, Frank and Just, Flemming (ed.): <i>Food and Conflict in Europe in the Age of the Two World Wars</i>. Basingstoke / New York: Palgrave, 2006, pp.&#160;143–171, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1403986843" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-4039-8684-3</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite conference (page does not exist)">Template:Cite conference</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
</ul>
